The food is great, though I usually go with my standby biryani or butter chicken and haven't quite gone through the entire menu yet. The whole fish looks amazing though and people sitting next to me have always seemed to enjoy it.
author: Mr. C.

description:
Some of the best Indian food you can in the Bay area. Authentic north Indian spicy food. I have been to this place several times and tried everything vegetarian on the menu. I have never been disappointed by the food. Really recommend the Paneer tikka from the tandoor and kofta.

The owners are super friendly and service is quite good. They have a small but complimentary selection of wine. 

It's a very small place so call ahead if you have a group greater than 4.
author: Kunal S.

description:
Rita, oh rita.  even when we 4 drunkards show up at the end of night, loud, starving, you are gracious, you stay open late, set our menu, even let us know we're ordering too much when we ask for more.  before saffron grill turned this corner bright, getting indian meant traveling to the mission or the loin.

if you're in these parts and you're hankering for indian, you can't do better than here for fresh and tasty eats and killer perfect pitch service.  like eating at a best friend's house in the nabe- familiar, comfortable, and getting the  most delectable lamb vindaloo, chicken tikka masala, and curry with shrimps,  and  meatless dishes too that don't disappoint, though aren't as memorable.
author: Nikki F.

description:
I had a take-out from Saffron grill when I was exploring for a new Indian restaurant to patronage.
I wasn't happy. I wouldn't recommend this place to any of my Indian friends. The food is just not spicy/savory enough. It's almost sweet. On the other hand, I imagine non-Indian palates new to Indian food might appreciate the food here.
I tried the chicken tikka masala and the chicken biryani.
author: Eyw d.

description: I love this place...its so small, quaint, unobtrusive...but the food is really good and the service is great.  It is never busy, sadly, but I suspect they do a rather large business of pick ups.  My roommate and I tend to go here when we both happen to be home at night and neither of us have eaten but we don't feel like grilling.  We go here, he has the chardonnay, I have the indian beer (fisher kind), we get some crispy bready thing, chicken tikka masala, naan bread and super yummy rice pudding.  The portions are great, its affordable and you never have to wait.  But, be careful, the spice will kick your ass, even if you think you can handle medium, you can't.  I know what you are thinking, but you still can't.  Unless you want to suck on fire, you can't handle it.
author: Kierstan G.

description: Family run neighborhood restaurant that was an enjoyable experience. Good service. Reasonable prices. Excellent food. If you live nearby, try it you'll like it.
author: Joe M.

description:
Really Yelp? City wide this is the third best result for Indian food? 

The naan was delicious, the ingredients were fresh, but the spice was completely missing.
author: Jenn W.

description:
EXCELLENT flavors without the guilt!  My favorite Indian dishes are the super-creamy (korma, tiki masala, and saag paneer, which I could eat every day for the rest of my life), but Saffron Grill prepares them light on the cream and oil, but heavy on the texture and flavor.  Each dish packed a punch of spices--not hotness, but flavor--including delightfully surprising chunks of fresh ginger.  Yum!  This means I can eat Indian food more often...and I'll try the butter chicken for dessert!

The naan was the best I've ever eaten: soft, yet fully cooked; lush flavor with almost no grease.

What makes me love this place more is that they delivered to me via the Divisadero 24!  That's right, folks: SF MUNI delivers.

An improvement would be the use of paper containers and bags.  Next time I'll order ahead and bring my own containers--no more plastic tubs and bags, please!
author: Diana P.

description:
It was a dark cold night.  We had wanted Sushi, but Ino Sushi was closed.  We wandered to some random organic sushi place the name of which eludes me, but the wait was over an hour.  We tried Little Star, but the wait was still over 1 hour.  So we randomly wandered into Saffron Grill and were hella not disappointed.  Then, many months later, which is to say, last Friday, we intentionally wandered into Saffron Grill and were once again pleasantly impressed.  

First, and amazingly, the waitress who is like a super waitress pro, a paragon of waitering, remembered us.  She particularly recalled that we tried to order too much naan, she told us not to, we ordered it anyways, and then didn't finish it.  This time she was like, hey, you didn't finish it last time, don't make the same mistake.  We did not make the same mistake.  By the way, the naan is tasty, even though it comes cut up in a basket.  

The curry itself is of course where this place shines.  It is much richer and perhaps a bit more tomatoey than I am trained to from my countless trips to Naan and Curry or Pakwan, but that just makes it tastier.  It is also significantly less greasy, which means I feel less gross afterwards.  The variety is exactly what you expect of curry places, plus one or two dishes not usually present.  Also, be sure to ask for the specials, the eggplant special I had was frigging ridiculously good.  So was the giant tandori fish Julia Z ordered.  Crispy on the outside, juicy and meaty on the inside.  

Of course, along with the quality of both the food and the service comes a price, in this case, the fact that unlike Naan and Curry or Pakwan, dining here will cost you $20 a person.  Maybe more when you order drinks.  But who cares, when the food is that good, a couple extra bucks is worth it, no?
author: Leon K.

description:
I don't visit this part of the City too often, but my gf suggested I do and to this place in particular.  So we drove up and tried it out.  I had a bunch of spicy food earlier in the day so I opted to have something pretty mild.  I went with a Paneer Tika Masala which was definitely mild and soothing to my stomach.  The prices are fine, and the service was pretty darn good.  The lady was pretty sociable and got along pretty good.

I enjoyed it, a good place overall.
author: Ren L.

description:
Total gem. Best Indian food this side of town.

Love their Sag Paneer and Lamb Vindaloo. Pass on the Chana Masala.

Good service too. And they deliver!
author: Chanel P.

description: This place is awesome! I've been coming here for about a year and it's the best indian food in the area. Rita (server) is awesome and always is really helpful with recommendations. I've ordered the Tikka Masala, the Lamb Korm, Saag Paneer, and Garlic Nan, and nothing has disappointed yet!
author: Tyler M.

description:
OK, so i loved everything except the large group who had two screeching hens (girls) that thought they were at bucca-di-beppo or chuckie cheese. the food is great, the service from the very cool and nice owners is incredible but this is not, let me repeat, THIS IS NOT FOR LARGE GROUPS. if you roll into this place with anymore than 4 people your not doing yourself or the rest of us any favors. 
this place is tiny tiny
author: Mattew W.

description:
Quaint, cozy, and filled with spice...and for those of us who really enjoy all that is yellow, this is the place to be. The food was delicious, but, honestly, there wasn't much of it for what we were paying. However, that's no reason not to try or not to return. 

I'll have everything on the menu please, with some garlic nan! Yum.
author: Liz A.

description:
I agree with Diana P's review - delicious and tasty Indian food with out the grease and cream.  I'm always on the prowl for good, tasty, but not greasy or buttery or creamy Indian food. We came tonight after reading yelp reviews and even scored rock star parking right outside.

The dishes come mild, but we got them medium and spicy.  The chicken tikka masala was delicious. The aloo gobi was also tasty. We ordered spicy on this, but it didn't seem that spicy. The chana masala had a spicier sauce to it. 

The decor inside is sparse and you do leave with a slight indian aroma, but hey, it's worth it to find delicious Indian food for a reasonable price.
author: Natalie S.

description:
All around great little restaurant (and it is tiny). The samosas and vegetable pakora are delicious. After 5+ visits, I can't say I've come across a dish I wouldn't recommend - that includes both the meat and the veggie - especially when eaten with the garlic nan. Add in the friendly service and reasonable beer and wine prices, and Saffron Grill is worthy of visiting any night of the week (except Monday when they're closed).

PS Make sure to get an order or two of Gulab Jamun to-go if you're too full for dessert.You won't be disappointed.
author: Franklin L.

description: This is by far my favorite Indian restaurant in the city. The service is great! The food is delicious! And the spiciness is there! I haven't had a bad dish in my three visits.
author: Derek F.

description:
Saffron Grill has the same extensive menu that just about every Indian place in the city has, but they are at the upper end of the quality scale. I really liked the Chicken Achar, which I ordered because I thought it was a rare unique dish at Saffron, but have since seen at several other places around the city. Still, it was very good - spicy, saucy, and flavorful like the best Indian dishes.

Last week I brought an Indian food newbie (apparently they exist - it's deeply depressing). I wanted to give him a gentle American introduction to Indian food. I chose a chicken tikka masala - who doesn't like that? - and the waitress recommended a lentil dish off the mythical vegan menu that she didn't bring us and i don't see on their website. The chicken tikka masala was great as always, but we weren't the biggest fans of the lentil dish.

Both times, after stating in no uncertain terms that I wanted it very spicy, they did a pretty good job and gave instructions on how to juice the chiles in the dish to add more heat if desired. I still would have liked more, but it's better than most places in SF have given me. The service was extremely friendly both times. I'll be back soon.
author: Adam B.

description:
Very tasty and completely worth the trek across the city so if you live close you really have no excuse not to try this place.

Like other reviewers I really appreciate that they have a special vegan menu.  It's so nice to not have to ask about the ingredients of everything when order.  I wish more restaurants would do this.

The vegan Saag Dal and Onion Roti were fantastic.  My companions said the Butter Chicken, Saag Paneer, Lamb Vindaloo, and Garlic Naan were some of the best they've had.

TIP: They listen when you say you want your food spicy. Whew! And they're good about keeping your water glass full.
author: Tessa M.

description: Don't understand the rave reviews, food was mediocre (nan was doughy, sag salty ...) for the price and the staff not so friendly. We have tried a lot of Indian restaurants in SF and Aslam's will continue to be our hands down favorite.
author: Jo D.

description:
This is a very quaint family-run restaurant.

It took me three years to final try out this place even though it's technically the closest restaurant to my house, and I'm pleased to say that it was worth the wait.  

I don't yet know what the in-house dining experience is like, but they are extremely friendly and provide quick service for take-out.  I'll be coming back here again very soon.
author: Miller H.

description: Absolutely best indian restaurant. Very spicy, very authentic. Owned by a fabulous family. Definitely go!
author: Jordana K.

description: It may not be the biggest place out there (if you've got a party larger than 4, you may have a wee bit of a hassle squeezing everyone in comfortably, depending), but it's got style and killer food to boot! Went here on a date, had lovely meal which included a great garlic naan and lamb vindaloo, and left with a worthy food coma and good memories.
author: Casey B.

description: Just discovered this little gem and went two nights in a row! Indian food is my favourite and have tried so many in the city that are just not up to scratch. The curries are to die for, the naan's melt in the mouth and the service comes with a massive smile and a whole lotta laughs if you get Rita. I'll be making many trips here in future.
author: Joanna R.

description: Great indian food!  All the classics on the menu.   Food comes out hot and fast.  Everything is reasonably priced.  Server was very good and my water glass was kept full.  I highly recommend this joint.
author: JT N.

description: Really good and super cute! Friendly service!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Craving some Indian, we checked this place out and were pleasantly surprised.

We ordered the curry combo meal (Chicken Tikka Masala, rice, nan/naan, and rice pudding) and then some lamb naan on the side. The Chicken Tikka Masala wasn't quite as flavorful as we have had at other places, but everything else was top notch. The lamb naan was an interesting pinkish hue too, which made it stand out from others we have had.

The service was also fast, although the place was a little cramped... but really the only notable downside to the restaurant.

All in all, we were impressed. Recommended and a place we consider worth checking out more than once.
author: Sami R.

description:
Ok - I just found this place and its now become my favorite Indian spot!

The Menu: 4-stars. Great classic selections and daily specials which are always a nice treat. But I have to give it 4 stars because my favorite dish is not on here - delicious Dopiaza. If they ever do add in on the menu (please!!!) I am sure they will make it just right!

The Food: 5-stars. Excellent. Fresh, flavored perfectly and quality ingredients.

The Staff: 10-stars. Um, I love these people. Namely the hostess. Not sure her name, but she seriously needs to be my friend - she is so funny. Any hostess that can sit at the table next to me and talk about Real Housewives of NJ is a kindred spirit.
author: Jesse V.

description:
Saffron Grill is the BEST shit in the entire world!! NOTHING is as good as this place. I'm obsessed with it. obsessed.

The pakoras are my faves. 

Not to mention Rita is the bomb. I love her! She's so nice and she takes care of you.

It's amazing. plain and simple. GO.
author: Regina P.

description:
If you like Indian food eat here, you'll love it! I've tried this lovely little restaurant several times and done takeout too. Last time we had the garlic nan, lamb biryani, raita, and delicious tandoori chicken. I've yet to try their other kinds of nan because the garlic nan is so good. When we ordered their two desserts--gulab jamun and rice pudding--my friend who knows Indian food mentioned another desert (I forget the name) that we should try and the waitress said: "we have that too, would you like to try it?" We had them with chai and they were all delicious! 

Consistently good food and consistently kind service. The servers have always been genuinely friendly. Try it, you'll like it!
author: Ron R.

description:
If you love delectable cuisine and delightful family own dinning experiences, then you will love Saffton Grill: North Indian Cuisine. 

the must haves:
Samosa, Papadum, Tandoori Chicken, Sag Paneer, and of course Raita w/ Nan. And if you have room for dessert Gulab Jamun. 

Yummy in my Tummy.
author: Julie S.

description:
The food is very, very good, especially the Chicken/lamb vindaloo. The service is great as well. 

My only complaint is that the dining area is small, a bit stuffy, and not all that comfortable. This is a minor complaint, though, and it should not stop you from trying this place (or just do take out!).
author: Dustin E.

description: My wife and I are full on addicted to Saffron Grill!  We live a couple of blocks from here and come at least every other Friday night.  First of all the service is amazing.  Such a cozy neighborhood feel and the owners are awesome.  The food is equally as amazing.  My wife is a vegetarian and is obsessed with the samosas, matter paneer and onion nan - but everything we have tried on the menu is amazing.  Be careful asking for your curry spicy though - it will dominate you!
author: Dan L.

description:
Are there any new places to eat on Divisadero?  We looked for some, and found this place.  What?  It's been open four months already?  

Around 5:20 pm we walked in and were seated in the window.  A little light conversation made us feel like we were right at home.  My Lady ordered a sauvignon blanc, and I ordered a Kingfisher.  Then we got down to the serious business of choosing our food.  We bypassed all the lamb dishes, seafood and curries, and ordered our favorites:  1/2 tandoori chicken and mixed vegetables, with sides of mango chutney and basmati.  

The chicken was perfect, both moist and tasty!  I enjoyed the mango chutney, as the slices of mango were satisfyingly large.  The dishes didn't look big individually, but they added up to a big meal overall, for  $37.27 + tip.  

Oh, yeah.  We knew it wasn't really new when we saw the "People Love Us On Yelp" sticker in the window, next to the credit card stickers.  We hope this restaurant will be in business for a long time.
author: David D.

description:
I always have my order to go: the restaurant is very cramped. But the food is great!

My go-to place for comfort food: Butter chicken, raita and Naan - never go wrong!
author: Aditi K.

description:
Delicious.  Unlike any other Indian food I've had in SF.  The flavors are layered and nuanced -- you can tell that a lot of thought and experience went into the food.  Even the website is very thoughtful and beautifully done.

My old standby for Indian was Indian Oven, but it's now been supplanted by Saffron Grill.
author: kevin c.

description:
I was very bummed out to learn that Kathmandu Cafe had closed.  Where else am I going to get Nepalese food?

I came in here expecting the new owners to have improved on Kathmandu Cafe's thrown-together decorations, but apparently, Saffron Grill's owners are either really into minimalism or are really cheap.  The place is spartan inside; the walls in my room have more art on them.  (OK, so that probably doesn't tell you much unless you've been inside my room, which you haven't.  I have one thing hanging on my wall.)

The food is good, and the service is attentive.  I like how when you sit at the table against the south wall that you can literally reach out and grab more utensils and napkins if you need them.  You can also grab the place's business license and pass it around the table, although I don't encourage this practice.  The menu's got all your favorites, and everything's just as spicy as I like it.  My main problem with Saffron Grill, though, is that the portions are pretty small.  

Saffron Grill is definitely an able replacement for Kathmandu, although if I had to choose one I would take the latter.  It is nice, though, to have a more traditional Indian restaurant in the neighborhood.  (Kathmandu had some Indian food, but it wasn't as spicy as I like it.)  Both restaurants garnered four stars from me, but Saffron Grill is definitely on the lower end of four stars.  It may even drop down to three.
author: John S.

description:
They closed an hour earlier than their stated time.

So my boyfriend and I trekked up to the city to celebrate Valentines Day tonight (Saturday) since we weren't able to do it on the 14th. We were both super jazzed about having Indian food and that this place got such good reviews. We called ahead to make a reservation at 9, and the employee my boyfriend spoke to said that a reservation would not be needed and to just come.

So after our parking adventure, we didn't get to the restaurant til about 9:30, however they immediately turned us away, stating that they were closed.  We mentioned that Yelp said they were open for another hour plus their own website says they are open til 11 on Saturdays.  The only response they gave was a shrug and that "it just happens."

Whatever their reason was for closing early, it has left an unfortunate first (and only) impression of their restaurant for me.
author: Nicole N.

description:
I thought this place was excellent.  Fresh, whole ingredients, excellent flavors, not oily, and very authentic.  We ordered the sag paneer, samosas, and mixed vegetable curry, btw.

The service was excellent (we were served by the same affable, fun, easy-to-talk-to waitress that others mentioned, and felt like we were being served dinner at a friend's home.  But the food!  Oh, the food! 
I hope you enjoy this little gem as much as I did.
author: Amy K.

description:
The food was absolutely amazing - quite possibly the best Indian food I have ever experienced.

The service was equally good - our waitress was extremely friendly, helpful, and attentive.

I would love to give Saffron Grill a 5 star rating, but unfortunately they have a serious issue with their ventilation system.  Don't get me wrong - there is no foul odor or anything like that...the problem (as explained by our waitress) has to do with the vent in the ceiling.  Somehow the air pressure is changing rapidly such that your ear drums actually oscillate.  It's not really a noise...more of a pressure and sensation on your ear drums.  I really hope they can address this issue because I would love to make this my go-to Indian restaurant.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Great food! My first time trying this neighborhood eatery and I cannot believe it took me so long. The food is very fresh and flavorful but could be more spicy for me. I'll mention that the next time I call because there will be a next time. 

I had the sag paneer and aloo gobi with naan.
author: Taisha R.

description:
Easily the best Indian food I have ever had. I had the Veggie Korma and It was clean, classy, and delicious. From the waitress who called me "hun" to the silent yet efficient waiter, the service was nice and on top of things.

Not the biggest place ever, but I do hope that they get even more successful. 

This restaurant will be the benchmark I will hold other Indian food to from now on. Go here, it's worth it.

5 stars!!!!!
author: Brian M.

description:
Awesome family-run restaurant!

Place is small and unimpressive in that regard.  In fact, it really looks like the size of a typical apartment living room in SF.

Anyways, food is top notch and if you like spicy, order it spicy!  I was sweating like a hostage.  I don't recall what I ordered, but it was a chicken, a fish, and lamb.  Masala?  Yes, one of the meats was that style.

Garlic naan was superb.  Warm and soft.

Bring a towel if you sweat, BTW.  But in regards to food, this place was SOLID!
author: Darren C.

description: Waited a long time for the reopen and it was worth it!!  Still our absolute favorite Indian restaurant, and with a husband born and raised in England where curry seems to be the national food, that really says something. Also, they make you feel as welcome as if you are going to their home for a dinner party.
author: Tess H.

description:
I've had take out from Saffron a couple times and have been pleasantly surprised both times. The butter chicken is delish and the lamb coconut curry is also very good. However, at most other places coconut curry is usally a little bit creamy, I don't know which way is the "traditional" way, but both are good. The samosas from Saffron are the absolute best I've ever had. The filling is really moist! 

Saffron is a little pricey but the quality is slightly better than the places I usually go to. The interior is really small, maybe 8-10 tables, so I think I'll stick with take out. This is a new neighborhood favorite for me!
author: Kandace K.

description:
On a recent trip to see the family on London I gorged on Indian food; it is so hard to find in San Francisco.

Now I'm back the craving is still there and I yelped this place a few blocks from home. Early days yet but I may have found that essential of life, the local curry house.

It's a small, family run place that's low on decor but high in other areas. I tried the combi lamb curry deal and was favorably impressed. 

The opening papadum was well done, with a couple of dipping sauces; one good, one not so good. A decent amount of rice and a pot of lamb achar went down very well - it's about five hunks of meat in a  rich tomato sauce. The accompanying nan bread was fresh and crisp too. 

Portion size was smaller than I've seen in other restaurants but certainly more than enough for me. Decent beer selection at bar prices.

The rice pudding to finish is, however, fantastic. It's sweet and savoury, and is perfect for cooling a hot mouth. 

So I'd give it four and a half stars, since the only complaint could be that it lacked atmosphere.
author: Iain T.

description:
Everything was superb. It's not quite the bargain price one usually expects for Indian food, but even writing this review the morning after dinner there, my stomach is growling for more.

It's a small family run place and everyone is very kind. The style is North Indian apparently. The father/chef made familiar dishes with exceptional skill in adding spices, making each dish truly unique and flavorful.

Also, importantly, they get the significance of atmosphere, something that is nearly always lacking in restaurants. The lights were dim, there was art on the walls, and soft Indian string and drum music played in this intimate setting of about 6 tables.

While I was eating someone had come from across town to pick up an order, so things are looking good. Good luck, Saffron!
author: Gregory F.

description:
Yellow garlic naan
Spice and ginger fill my mouth
Hostess eyeliner
author: HaikuReview S.

description:
Really disappointing experience with Saffron Grill tonight, and I am seeing that the reviews have dipped in the last few months, so perhaps I'm not alone. We've come here to eat in and get take out on several occasions over the past couple of years. It's always been flavorful, friendly service, and reasonably priced. The place had a fire about 18 months ago and we eagerly kept track of its progress to reopening. We enjoyed a great meal a few months back after they got back into business.

Tonight, though, the food was supremely disappointing. We called ahead for a to-go order, were told it'd be 15 minutes, showed up when predicted, and the food was definitely not ready. They must have neglected to even make it, cause we had to wait for about 15 minutes to get it to go. Got it home, and opened our containers for Coconut Chicken Curry and Navratan Korma, which we'd had before and loved. This time, instead of the creamy, orange-colored, smooth sauce enveloping chunks of well-spiced vegetables, the dish looked like a package a frozen vegetables got thrown into some light cream, with some cursory spices sprinkled on it. The veggies were mushy and the sauce bland, bland, bland. And, instead of being suspended in the delicious spicy cream goodness, they were just kind of falling apart out of the sauce. The Chicken dish was fine, but the garlic naan, too, was so subpar. Dry, with no whiff of garlic, hardly any butter, close to zero flavor. I've had the naan in the restaurant and take out several times, but this was like someone had sprinkled two shreds of cilantro on a pita and wrapped it up to go. Severely disappointing all around.

I used to love this place, but this was like 3 strikes all at once (lost our order; crappy navratan korma; a joke of a garlic naan). Not sure I'll be going back after this sorry excuse of an Indian meal from a place I know has done better.
author: Nika T.

description:
How many times have I groaned about the lack of cuisines in Nopa? Kind of a lot. But now we have Saffron Grill ... a pretty sweet spot for those times when you just want to roll out in your PJs for a low-key, tasty meal served by low-key, nice people. 

The menu is quite extensive, the portions are fair, and the small space is bearable as long as there aren't too many people. We went all out (by our standards) and had 3 beverages, an appetizer, 2 entrees, 1 naan, and 1 rice for $50 including tax and tip. At first I thought the entrees were too mild, but I came to appreciate the subtle flavors and remembered that dishes don't all have to hit you over the head to be good! The price is fair -- you're paying for quality and home-cooked goodness. 

Now can someone please open up a bakery or noodle shop?
author: Sumi Y.

description:
Ordered takeout for the second time from Saffron Grill and was, again, delighted to find the food fresh, hot and delish.The samosas were terrific. awesome vegetarian options. Love the mixed vegetables and garlic naan.

The staff is extraordinarily nice. Its a bit pricey, but the portions are generous.
author: Rena B.

description:
I was looking for a place to meet friends for dinner, and since we were in the mood for Indian we decided to meet here. We arrived at 6:00 pm on a Wednesday and it didn't look like much from outside. Also, we could see from the window that the place was empty (it was still early). Since Yelp reviews were so amazing, we went for it anyways... and boy are we glad we did! 

The decor of the place is cute and welcoming. It's not a very big restaurant, which gives that good ol' cozy hole in the wall feeling.

Our waitress was incredible - she greeted us like guests in her home, gave suggestions when we couldn't make up our minds, and was generally friendly and helpful. 

And, as can be expected, the best part was the food. Very flavorful with an authentic, home-made tasting kick. The garlic naan was also our of this world.

Apparently a lot of people know about place, because by 6:45 or 7:00, as we were finishing our meal, the place was packed... people were waiting for tables. Good thing we came early!
author: Vanessa F.

description:
Given the reviews, I was really excited to check this place out. I grew up in a family that ran Indian restaurants, so I know a lot about how they are run and what a good curry is. That said, I was super disappointed with Saffron Grill. 

We waited 35 minutes for a table, which was to be expected, but once seated it took them another 20 minutes to take our order and another 50 minutes after that for our food to come out. They didn't check on us--it seemed like more of an avoidance tactic given the tiny size of the place. There was a point where no tables had any food on them and people were complaining, yet they were bringing tons of food out for delivery. Eventually I saw that tables that came in 15-20 minutes after us were receiving food, so I asked about our order and the waiter seemed very confused and without checking said "another ten minutes". Of course, 30 seconds later our food came out. 

Overall the food was fine to good, but not worth the $2-4 extra per item you pay here compared to other Indian restaurants in the city, especially given the super slow service and the nasty unkempt bathroom (just a new coat of paint would help!). I think if people are looking for non-creamy Indian restaurants they should just look for north Indian (vs south Indian) spots and they'll see there is a lot of better Indian food out there.
author: Sara W.

description:
Replacing the Kathmandu Cafe, Saffron Grill fills what could have become a huge void in our neighborhood with a tasty North Indian menu. Service was great, and if you ask them to, they'll make the dish as spicy as you want. The malai kofta was great!

We were very happy with the food and very much relieved to still have a go-to place for when we're too lazy to cook and need some Indian fare.
author: Robert T.

description: D-LISH.  Located 2 blocks from my house, and 3 years later and I finally try SG.  I would drive 50 miles to eat more of their Sag Paneer and Biryani. not greasy and a great price point.
author: Megan M.

description:
I am going to be in the minority here it seems but I am soo bummed we lost Kathmandu Cafe and I really don't think that Saffron Grill is an equal replacement. 

I won't spend this review regaling you with stories of Kathmandu (although I have many) instead I will focus on Saffron. 

I have been here a couple times and I have to say it all seems pretty run-of-the-mill, I heart Indian so I am okay with that, but I just wish they had one or two dishes that would make an impact and make me WANT to return here, not just return for lack of better indian options in the area.
author: Marissa C.

description: Delicious little Indian restaurant that my wife and I happened upon. We loved everything that we ordered. Just keep in mind that it's in a fairly small space, and probably isn't ideal for larger groups.
author: Matt D.

description:
This place is A-OK.

service was friendly and all smiles.
prices were average
fair portions

we were upset at first cause on the menu they charge you for the chutney and yogurt sauce.  but then they gave us a free papadum with a side of it so all was good.

bill for 2 entrees was $28
author: Josie M.

description:
Its nice to have a new food option near my house.
Especially Indian...

I have ordered to go from here twice in the last 2 weeks and am addicted!

I loved the chicken achar, it has this lightly pickled flavor.  

The mattar paneer, my favorite is done right with lots of cheese and not mushy peas...

I always order the keema nan at any indian restaurant. This one is pretty good.

Im looking forward to checking out the rest of the menu and dining in next time.
author: Karlee D.

description:
This place is a gem tucked away off of Divis in Western Addition/NOPA.  They have the most amazing servers, specifically the girl who is part owner with her family.  She brightens my day when I come by with her sincere greeting and very attentive service.  The food is amazing.  The fish masala is to die for, as is the saag paneer.  They will deliver if you live close by, which I do.  To eat there, definitely call ahead, because it's small and usually busy every night (for good reason).  This is my favorite Indian in the city, based on food and service and atmosphere equally!

Sidenote, the portions are huge.  I ordered delivery for 3 people (3 entrees, saffron rice, veggie somosas, and naan) which was $56 and we had enough entrees for 2 more meals afterwards.  Just as good reheated as the first time around!  LOVE IT!
author: Meg G.

description:
I was really eager to try this place. I saw some advert with a pretty picture and read a raving review. I thought, no way, a new upscale Indian eatery? I have to try it! After bugging Kristy H, we finally found ourselves there when the wait for Nopalito was too long.

This place is not fancy. In fact, it felt like we were eating at someones house. Mostly empty tables. Weird yellow paint job on the walls (maybe that is why it felt like someone's house because its the same color as my kitchen). The metal grill over the skylight say's "Mr. D's" (bet that was a fun joint).

But the food. The food wasn't too bad. The curries were HOT. OK, maybe white guy hot, but I think I have a pretty good  heat tolerance and this was on the hot side. The Naan was yellow with garlic. The water refills just kept coming. If I lived in this hood, I would probably hit them up for take out.
author: Zac H.

description: As much as I love supporting my neighborhood businesses, I don't think I'll be dining here as often as I would like. As a stand-alone place, it's not bad. Cute, quaint, decent food. Unfortunately they were destined to be compared to their predecessor, Kathmandu Cafe, which had better food and better prices. And really, it's the prices that bother me. $11.25 for Chicken Tikka? Fine, if you give me decent portions, but with just a few chicken pieces in a small metal bowl of sauce, I found myself needing more. For a casual neighborhood place, I would prefer not to spend $15-20 a person and only feel kinda full.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
We had the chana masala and the chicken vindaloo, along with naan and rice. The chicken vindaloo was spicy, flavorful and delicious - if you ask for "spicy", definitely be prepared for some heat. Although the spiciness was definitely worth it and didn't overwhelm the flavor. 

The chana masala was a little bit bland, although it was spicy it was just missing some flavor, maybe salt or something.  The naan was chewy and hot, but a little bit greasy.

Overall I would definitely order from here again - if you love spicy Indian food I'd recommend it. Great prices too, it would be good to try more of their dishes next time.
author: Erin B.

description:
If this review was for the service alone, I would give 5+ stars! They were fabulous. Of course, that could be because we were the ONLY table in the place the entire time, but nontheless.... 

If this review was for the food alone, I would give perhaps 4 stars. I ordered the lamb korma, which was pretty good. I also tried my friend's biryani, which was OK. My naan was also just OK (a little oily, actually). The veggie samosas were filled with diced potatoes rather than mashed, which I don't prefer, but some might. 

Here's where they lose out: any place that doesn't include raita with the biryani and charges extra for it will always automatically lose a star for being cheap and greedy. Also, the portions were so small that any thought of leftovers was quickly forgotten when I finished the last of about 5 small chunks of lamb in my korma. Especially for the prices!! Ohmygod were the prices high for what you're actually getting. Now, I'v been to other high-end (almost fine dining-like) Indian places with prices that high, but you have food for 3 days left over! And this is far, far from a fine dining establishment. 

Overall, cute place that I might go back to if I'm going to be in that vicinity for something. But it's more likely that I'll head over for pizza instead. It's cheaper and more filling.
author: Amy B.

description:
While we were sad to see Kathmandu Cafe go,
we are thrilled to welcome Saffron Grill to our humble 'hood.

They did a nice job remodeling 
- warm yellow walls with some colorful Indian accents
amd some cheerful colored lights in the window.

Great, fresh food at a good price along with friendly, professional service.
We will definitely come back for the Lamb Achar (house specialty) and Butter Chicken, but also look forward to try out other interesting menu items. 
Heard some raving about the Tikka Masala from our table neighbors, so that's definitely on the list ...
author: Francis S.

description:
first off I want to give it a 2.5 stars and I don't believe this place deserves 3 stars, so 2 stars it is...

I ordered a couple of combo meals to go, lamb sag and chicken tikka masala.  each combo meal came with rice, entree, naan and rice pudding.  the prices are kind of high.  for the 2 combo meals it came out to $38.

I have two main complaints.  the lamb sag only had 3-4 pieces of meat.  the chicken was tastier but didn't pay attention to how many pieces of meat were in it.  the rice was a little dry and chewy, like day old rice.  it wasn't fresh.  because of the quality of the rice, the lack of meat and the high price this place deserves only 2.5 stars.

I work in the south bay and been to quite a few indian restaurants.  saffron grill does not compare.  even though most in the south bay are buffets, they have a big selection of dishes, food made fresh, it's cheaper and it's all you can eat.  I believe the indian food in the south bay is much better than the ones in sf.
author: Samson M.

description: Quaint. Simple. Good. You have to sit close to other customers. Yes, feels like fam. No seriously though it's a great spot and the food is good. When they say spicy they actually mean spicy. Not kill-you/ prove-you-are-a-real-man-yearning-for-colon-cancer spicy, but they bring the heat within reason. Nevermind, spicy is really tough to convey over Yelp. I liked the Korma and the Saag Ghosht (sp?).
author: Konrad P.

description: I'm new to SF and after living in Berkeley for 5 years I didn't think I would find a yummy Indian restaurant, but I did. Delish, fresh and NOT greasy! I have eaten at a lot of Indian places and while they might be cheap they were also greasy. Food was flavorful and service was great. Best of all is down the street from me. Will go again for sure.
author: Alana R.

description:
My boyfriend and I love this place.  The food is delicious, and the servers are always extremely nice.  

The vegetable samosas are great, but they are big - if you're not very hungry one of these and an entree is more than enough.   Speaking of entrees, my boyfriend loves the Chicken Tikka Masala, and I highly recommend the Vindaloo for those unafraid of spice (they'll make it more mild if you like).  We generally round out the meal with garlic naan, which has just the right amount of garlic for me - and I'm fairly picky about garlic.  We've only had dessert a couple times (since we're generally stuffed by that point); the rice pudding has a great flavor, but is sometimes a little runny for my taste.     

The small space feels homey to me, nothing fancy but friendly and warm whenever I go in.
author: Katie P.

description:
I am excited to report that Saffron grill is even better than the Katmandu cafe it replaced! 

The food is still excellent. I am admittedly your chicken tikka masla fan, but I went with the house specialty, the chicken achar, and fell in love with the succulent chicken and tangy taste.

The service and warmth is superior to Katmandu, 5 stars to the waitress who would not bring us our check until we finished our 22 once Taj beers.
author: ellen m.

description: I judge my Indian restaurants by their chicken tikka masala.  And by far, they serve the BEST compared to all the ones I've tried across San Francisco and this country!  The sauce is the right amount of creaminess and spice.  And after the meal, the aftertaste even leaves you salivating for more.  Try their garlic naan...also really good.
author: Marko M.

description: I really enjoy the food but they've stopped answering their phone. The last time I attempted to call an order in they hung up on me.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Indian food is one of my favorite cuisines, and I've eaten it a lot in this city.  I wish I could agree with everyone else here, but I just wasn't impressed.  I really wanted to like it, the woman working as the hostess/waitress was extremely friendly and warm.  No stars deducted for service that's for sure, but I was underwhelmed by the food.  

They gave us a complimentary pappadam with tamarind and mint chutney to start.  Nothing too exciting, but a nice touch.  We had the malai kofta and the chicken sagwala, garlic naan, and basmati rice.  The malai kofta had an overwhelming amount of ginger (my favorite place for this dish in SF Is Mehfil) and the chicken sagwala was okay but a bit watery with a lot of ginger too.  The garlic naan was also okay, but not very fluffy (Lahore Karahi's is much better).  

The oddest thing is that they brought out plates for our entrees with what I assume is a garnish of sliced iceberg lettuce and cucumber, but the lettuce was slightly browning and wilting.  It would have been better just to get a clean plate with nothing on it.  

I might try it again in a few weeks, but for now I'll still be going to the Tenderloin for Indian food.
author: Joann C.

description:
I'm having a hard time understanding the high reviews for this place, this is by far the worst, most disgusting Indian food I have ever eaten. Everything we ordered was bland and the portions were extremely small. We ordered the chicken tikka masala and the  veggie korma. Both were watery and in need of any type of spice or flavor. 

I'd recommend passing on this place, there are better, cheaper Indian places in the city.
author: Dom And Jazz C.

description: hands down the best indian food i've ever had and the couple that owns are amazing. i was so sad when they were closed from the fire and it is so great to see them open again. i moved out of the neighborhood so i'm mostly getting delivery from them but it's still delicious! i suggest the samosas, butter chicken, and the saag paneer.
author: Mary H.

description:
Went here for lunch on my last day living in the 'hood and was pretty disappointed.

I thought they had lunch specials, but when I got there it seems they're only to go?  Pretty lame.

Service was pretty nonexistent, dude seemed like he was more interested in playing with his laptop than serving us.

We got chicken sagwala, lamb achar, rice and naan.

The naan had puddles of oil on it, once I soaked it up with a napkin it was good, the rice was completely plain (I guess I'm used to a little cardamon and clove), the chicken sagwala was good and the lamb achar came to us as chicken achar and was also good.

Portions are small.

Did I mention that we were the only people there?  Boo.  All that ran me like $35 as well.  I felt kind of ripped off actually.
author: Rachel N.

description:
I don't consider myself an Indian Cuisine expert.... but I've tried a few things over the years.  This place was comfy, casual and the food is amazingly tasty!!!!!  Great location too... Divis and Fulton right down the street from Alamo Park!
We had the Lamb Boti Kabob, Chicken Vindaloo and Lamb Nan.  The lamb was to die for--- marinated in yogurt and spices which made it nice and juicy!  The Chicken Vindaloo was amazing as well.... the sauce was fantastic and the chicken was tender.  
Since the restaurant is family-owned, it was pleasantly intimate and an awesome neighborhood spot.  The service was great too!
I think I'll make this a regular stop!
author: anna p.

description:
Saffron Grill is an excellent option for good food at a good price. It's made all the more sweet by the fact that it's in the hood. 

A group of us went in there kind of late around New Year's and they were so accommodating that I wanted to follow up with the review I thought of writing at the time. We had several dishes, all of which were yummy. It's fuzzy but I remember that the food was tasty, the breads were delicious and the spices perfect. I also remember asking about their paneer: whether it was made locally and fresh. And indeed it is. I haven't had that quality of paneer since India and it was delicious.

The owner and cook were super nice and came out to chat with us while we were eating. They were eager for feedback and accepted our compliments with gratitude. They were very sweet and I think the cook is the owner's mother. You can't go wrong there.

So, if you're in the hood and hungry for some superlative Indian food, mosey on over to Saffron Grill. They've redecorated and are extremely happy to feed you. The food is excellent; you won't be disappointed.
author: Corey F.

description:
My friend and I were craving Indian food one night we were in town so we went on a search for an Indian restaurant. Saffron Grill was close by and the reviews seemed good enough. 

The restaurant is super tiny....we got lucky enough to snag a table a few minutes after we walked in.  The service was pretty poor...we waited a while for all of our food and we didn't see our server too many times.  

The food was alright.  Veggie samosas and pakoras to start which were both fantastic.  My Paneer Makhani was decent but it felt like something was missing.  I'm used to Indian dishes being super rich and flavorful but this dish was just coming up short.  My friend got some sort of vindaloo and also felt that it lacked flavor.  The naan was standard but rice needed to be ordered separately for $3?  I'm used to all of my orders at an Indian restaurant coming with a side of basmati.  

I've had some pretty terrible Indian food in the past, so that's the only reason why this place is getting three stars...it's a decent place to eat.
author: Megan D.

description:
Simply amazing Indian food!! Went here a few nights ago, and had one of the best dinners in a long time. The staff was friendly and helpful (even gave us choices for other Indian restaurants to try in town over next few days). 

The food was perfectly spiced and seasoned. Went with standards (Chicken Tikki Masala, Chicken Korma)--chicken was tender, tasty. Spices complemented the dishes. The garlic naan was delicious. The samosas were perfect, as were the chutneys. 

Will definitely return, and highly recommend Saffron Grill!
author: Ron H.

description:
Libra J.'s review is spot on.
Eating at this restaurant is like joining an Indian family for dinner.
If the restaurant in Today's Special truly existed, ( http://www.todaysspecial.com/ ) this would be it at its peak.
author: grep d.

description:
On Saturday I dinned at this tiny Indian Restaurant. This is really a neighborhood place with neighbors walking by and coming in. 

The waitress was really fun and had good suggestions. The menu is really large for the size of the restaurant. Highlights were Sag Paneer and Marinated Lamb. The food is not too spicy and you can really taste the flavors. The portions were a good size and this is a fun place to go with friends trying Indian food for the first time or on a date. 

Check it out.
author: elissa s.

description: I'm upgrading this place because I just love it so much. NEVER had a bad experience here. Love the lovely lady who runs the place - she cracks me UP! Love that it's a family-run place. Love that there's NO FLOCK WALLPAPER. Yeah.
author: Mi M.

description:
Love the lentil soup.  The wife loves the yellow dal.  The chicken tikka masala is good as well.

Limited selection of beer and wine.

Service is always friendly.
author: John D.

description:
If this place wasn't a couple of blocks from my house I wouldn't ever go.

The food is pretty good, though a little on the spicy side for my sensitive buds. 

Ordering for pick-up is a pain. They are very very slow and do not accurately predict the amount of time it will take for them to prepare your food.

I really like the main server though, she is super nice and doesn't seem to look down on me when i ask her for my food to be "super super mild, please"

As I said, the food is pretty good, just nothing super special. If you are in the neighborhood and craving indian then swing by. (or go to metro a few blocks away which is a pricier but my preferred place, personally)
author: Sandra E.

description: I have been going to Saffron Grill since it opened and we've been getting take out about once a month ever since. I have always felt lucky to live just up the street from a wonderful Indian restaurant.
author: Donna B.

description: So sad that we only discovered this place (good walking distance from our apt) just before we moved! I was on the trip with Elaine O and thought all 3 were so good. the butter chicken was my least fav, but I still enjoyed it. They also had a local artist's stuff on the walls and his stuff was great. I even got my fav piece for a bday present! The (family?) staff were great and friendly. SG inspired me to find indian places in Houston..
author: Lauren J.

description:
I was particularly sad to learn a few months back that the Kathmandu Cafe had shut their doors. For years, it had been one of my favorite secret/sacred little neighborhood joints to hit up for an intimate, quiet meal. On the bright side, it was immediately clear that the setting remained more or less the same the very moment I walked into Saffron Grill. But honestly, how can it not? The space is pretty tiny.

Our waitress was friendly & affable & full of giggles, so immediately the mood was friendly. We ordered a lamb dish & a chicken dish, BOTH were superb, although the reddish color of the lamb gave me a moment of pause. After a quick meeting on the mound with our waitress, she assured us that it wasn't undercooked. Sure enough, it tasted just fine.

I'm not a huge fan of Indian food (it's not one of my go-to cuisines), but when the mood strikes, I know now that Saffron Grill does it right. I will most certainly be back.
author: Pete J.

description: I was very impressed by this place! I had chicken tikka masala and it was filled with flavor and heat. The lady said medium breaks a sweat here and she was right. The medium was hotter than any extra hot I've had anywhere else in the US. It wasn't unbearable heat, just perfect!
author: Coen H.

description:
I think this place has the best service ever! The waitress was always attentive and helpful, never let our water glasses get below half.
The menu has great variety and the prices are great. I'm usually a meat eater so for me to eat a vegetarian meal, it's gotta be great. And it was! I ordered the lentil plate and had some jasmin rice. The portions are good, not too large but definitely not small.
Will be here again soon!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Two Words: Food Poisoning. 

I went there with 5 friends on Friday night. We had each been there before, and the food was great and nobody got sick. However, after our meal last Friday night each and every one of us got food poisoning. 

The sad thing is, the food tastes great. But not good enough to warrant the chance of getting poisoning. 

Oh, and also, the amount of chicken in their chicken dishes was lacking for a $12-$13 meal. 

They are nice and the food is good...but I wish:
1. They put more meat in the dishes
2. They not get me sick
author: Jack B.

description: It was MEH...not great...not bad...but not worth the money.  With all the rave reviews I wasn't sure what happen.  Sadness.
author: Pawanpreet G.

description: This is a small and friendly Indian restaurant located on Fulton near Alamo Square Park. I usually prefer frequenting Indian buffets for ~$10-12, but this place really makes me reconsider since you can actually taste the superior quality of the dishes. We came here around 8:30 PM on a Thursday night and the restaurant was nearly full. We were promptly seated and served complimentary papadum (thin slightly spicy Indian crackers) with two different chutneys (one sweet one spicy). We shared the chicken tikka masala (boneless chicken in a garlic and tomato sauce) and lamb korma (boneless lamb in a creamy cashew, raisins and saffron sauce), with side orders of garlic naan and rice. Wow you can actually tell they use high quality ingredients with a specific emphasis on tenderness and freshness. The chicken and lamb were extremely tender while the curries melded perfectly with the rice and naan. I especially loved the creamy cashew sauce in the lamb korma and couldn't get enough of it! The portion sizes were definitely generous enough to share. Service was very attentive without interfering with your conversation. Lastly, remember to make reservations if you plan to come with a larger group since it doesn't look like this place seats more than 20-25. All in all, the prices are on the higher side for the typical SF Indian restaurant, but I would consider returning here every once in awhile for quality Indian food. Wavered between 3 and 4 stars, but rounded up due to the superior quality.
author: Andy C.

description:
I have tried a lot of indian restaurants in the city. Saffron grill was pretty good- Liked the ambiance-quiet and cozy. I am genereally frightened of ordering tikka masalas in indian restaurants here- but i was quite pleased with what they served- it was adequately rich and i could taste the fresh tomatoes. 
And the samosas were pretty good too.

Alu gobi was pretty good- but nothing extraordinary. I was deeply disappointed with their plain naan. But overall i would go back and try their other items on the menu.
And yes it is a little pricey.
author: Diya G.

description:
Quickly- seems pretty standard Indian cuisine at a pretty standard price with great table service.

In more detail-  I rolled in about 9:50pm (they're open until 10:30!) and sat at the first table by the window.  I guess it was Rita (from other reviews) who served me and yes, she was very friendly and bubbly without being at all annoying.  I told her what type of dishes I liked and she recommended the house specialy, Chicken Achar, describing it as "tangy" and that it could be cooked as spicy as I like.

I was served a pappadum with both the tamarind and the cilantro sauces and honestly they tasted a bit more homemade than usual, especially the cilantro sauce was much spicier than any I'd ever had.  My main dish was served literally within about 4-5 minutes of ordering.

I had asked for "medium" spicy but found the dish to be a little hotter than anticipated.  It would probably benefit and allow more of the subtle flavors through if it was ordered mild.  Regardless, it was a somewhat tangy, tomato-based curry that was pretty good/average but also seemed to get better as it cooled off temperature-wise.  My rice could have been fresher but since I had come in so late....The garlic nan was also fairly typical but with turmeric added to the butter to add some flavor and color.  

Overall the food was very solid and typical Indian food, of an acceptable portion and helped along by friendly and attentive service.  The price is right but once you add some tea, nan and the annoying charge for rice it is no longer super-budget., but still reasonable.  Based upon my single experience at the Saffron Grill I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if you're in the neighborhood at 9:50pm, then by all means go!
author: Sweet T.

description: After getting violently ill for the second time after eating the mixed vegetables, it can no longer be a coincidence.  Sorry SG, your food is okay, but not so great coming up.
author: Janelle F.

description: To accompany the butter chicken, tikka masala and khorma, the three of us shared a bread basket, three different varieties of naan, and had two servings of rice between us. I have knocked off a star as I think the prices are such that rice should be included. The flavors were really good and everything we ordered was delicious. The service was really friendly, much more so than most Indian restaurants where they are efficient but not chatty and welcoming. Now if we could just transport Saffron Grill to Downtown Houston it would be perfect.
author: Elaine O.

description: The best Indian in San Francisco. Full of flavor but not heavy. Fresh, fresh fresh. Properly cooked. Delicious every time. A staple and a favorite. This is THE place for Indian.
author: Paul O.

description: So they say they deliver but it's not true. I have been here and the food is good but the last time I called I was told they were to busy to deliver, then I asked if I could do carry out and was again told no. I really don't understand and think that maybe they don't like money...
author: Isaac R.

description:
After going to Dosa, I was hesitant to go anywhere else for Indian food.
But I'm glad I did. The YELP reviews are true... everyone here is SUPER friendly. I ordered takeout-- chicken tikka kebab, chicken vindaloo, and nan. It was freakin delicious. YUMMY YUMMY YUMMY!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
i can tell that this place makes good food. the chicken tikka masala had a really fresh taste to it. you could tell they use fresh herbs and spices. but(!) there was an overwhelming taste of ginger and upon further inspection i found whole 1 inch shreds of ginger strips in the sauce. for those who like ginger, great. for me, not so great. 

oh, and it was nearly $17 for chicken tikka masala, one order of rice and one order of plain naan. a bit too much if you ask me. nonetheless, i think they serve good food but i won't be back because i don't like tons of ginger.
author: Regina C.

description:
Great new Indian spot in the hood!  Whoo hoo!  I was pretty pumped to try this place since I'm an out of the closet Indian food addict, and this place got me my fix in a perfect way.  I wanted to challenge the kitchen and my taste buds, so I got the seafood combo curry (tillapia and shrimp).  I asked for it extra spicy and I got exactly that.  My face was on fire, Homie!  Most places don't deliver the burn when I order it, but Saffron Grill was up for the task.  You don't have to get anything spicy at all (they custom fit it for you), but I like to know that they can turn it into overdrive for me.

This place is not much for decor, and it's pretty small so you'll be enjoying everybody's conversation and you'll be stared at by the too many employees.  There's 10 tables and 3 servers...maybe it seemed overstaffed since it was a quiet night, but there was nothing for these people to do.  No big woop, the attention on me was welcome, they are so eager to please.

Great naan, not huge portions, but huge flavor, and NOT GREESEY at all.  I'm a huge fan, I'll be back often!
author: Jon S.

description: Best Indian food I've eaten in SF, hands down and I'm Indian! Totally unexpected - family run, incredibly tasty, def going back...
author: A P.

description: We ordered a bunch of different dishes but the stand outs were the butter chicken, lamb vindaloo, and prawn masala.  And the naan.  Shoot, I pretty much listed everything I ate there.  The chicken was very tender and not dry at all, the sauce for the vindaloo was bursting with tang and flavor, and the prawns were clearly fresh and had a crunchy, juicy texture that only fresh shrimp can have.  It's a small, cozy restaurant and always seems to be packed.  I would not recommend coming here in a big group.  The restaurant is family run with the daughter serving the front and the dad busting out dish after dish in the back.  They're also not kidding about the spice.  If you can't handle spicy, you should proceed with caution.  But if you're a spicy lover like me, this will hit the spot.  If you're in the area, this is a great place for dinner.
author: Justine L.

description:
I moved into this neighborhood October 2011. I've walked by this restaurant before and finally went last evening. Fantastic! I've had a lot of good Indian food over the years. The kitchen delivered exactly what I requested, at the heat requested: Fish Masalla, Garlic Nan. The rice was perfectly prepared - I tasted it by itself and a few forkfuls later it rested my fork - savory and delicious. I ordered the Fish Masalla "Mexican spicy" (which I assumed would be a bit less than "Indian hot")...It was so perfectly prepared, and indeed was quite spicy hot, but only within the context of its delicious flavors. I took the rest home, and just this morning had the rest. I know, not exactly breakfast fare, but even the garlic nan held up well in the microwave. This leftover meal from the microwave almost tasted just like at the restaurant.

Those folks who have criticized "mild" preparations of "chicken tikka masalla" - I think it may come from failure to specify exactly what you want. This place is everything you would specifically like it to be.
author: Richard P.

description:
We went there after the very positive reviews this place had on yelp. Total let-down. We ordered the nans- biryani -  tikka masala - and some other stuff. The taste was not authentic at all. It was too ketchup-ish. Not enough flavour , the service was a MAJOR thumbs-down. 

The naans were good. 

My reference for the one star is other Indian restaurants in the bay area and food I have had back in Delhi. 

STRONGLY DO NOT RECCOMMEND
author: ORIJIT D.

description: This place does awesome Indian, and they have a secret vegan menu. Love it!
author: Daniel B.

description: Chicken Tikka Masala left a lot to be desired.  Service was fine but i won't be dining there again.
author: Pauline R.

description:
We had had a drink or two at bar 821 and were feeling peckish. We googled places in the area and Saffron Grill was not on there...we just spotted it out of the corner of our eyes- an inviting, warm light in the freezing cold mist....

Now my belly is full of fire!

Had a great meal here, I was going to stay just for starters (to get home and in bed at a decent time), but I ended up staying till the very end, sugar-coated fennel on the way out and all! 

We ordered pakora and chicken chaat for starters, along with papadums (really good, cracked black pepper-enhanced, crunchy texture..yum, and Im not even a papadum fan normally).  The pakora came in abundance- not too greasy, full of yummy vegetables and healthy chick pea flour. 

We ordered yellow dahl (extra spicy), Lamb vindaloo (awesome sauce, tender lamb), Sag Paneer (always my favorite, rich, creamy spinach and yummy chunks of paneer cheese), and Aloo Gobi (big pieces of cauliflower and spicy potatoes, tons of spices). We got wholewheat roti, warm, fresh naan and white rice. (Naan can be so hit-or-miss, and this was a hit.) 

We were a party of 5 and there were still left-overs, we giggled as we scooped the leftovers into various take-away boxes. We were just so full. And the bill was just SO reasonable. Always a feel-good factor. 

The waitress, Rita, was hilarious, she told us to get up and run around the block so we could finish the food. She asked us why we were so red 'your faces are the color of the vindaloo sauce' and made us laugh over and over. Great family atmosphere, and really lovely home-like interior with nice art and pretty colored lights.

Yup, all in all, a great place to eat and relax. I'd had a major Indian food craving for a while and the hearty fare at Saffron Grill really hit the spot. 

Of course, the great company I was with enhanced the overall greatness of the dining experience :)

I don't need to eat till at least Saturday! 

Go to Saffron Grill.
author: Tara S.

description: Hands down my favorite Indian Restaurant in the Bay!  I was back last night and had super excellent service, as well as fantastic grub.  The Chicken Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala, and Butter Chicken are some of my faves.  The Garlic Naan rocks my world.
author: Mara C.

description: WORST experience I have ever had in my history of dining out! But i'm at odds with everyone else, it must have been the staff that served me on this particular day!  So disappointed right now... Oh yeah, I remember.... the chicken was SOOO disgusting, i didn't even want to feed my dog with it but since I don't like wasting food that's pretty much what I did... She devoured it, cause you know, she's a dog... but I warn you.... don't go there.
author: Adriana T.

description: Tikka Masala bland, Tandori Chicken forgettable, I tell ya what though that saag paneer, best consistency in the city. So if you are into Paneer this is your place... Its cozy, nice neighborhood setting, just needs alil more kick.
author: C. Robert D.

description: I come from an Indian family with amazing cooks. Unfortunately, they live an hour away and I can't always get the home cooking I crave! I am SO happy that I tried Saffron Grill. The most amazing Indian I've had away from home, EVER. I had the Chicken Achar, the Paneer Mukhani, and garlic naan.  The food was so fresh, spiced to perfection and delicous!!! My experience with most San Francisco Indian restaurants is that they use a lot of packaged Indian masalas filled with sodium and MSG- Saffron does not! I can't wait to try other items on their menu!
author: Jayshree K.

description:
This place is small, cute, and dimly lit in a romantic sort of way. It gets a bonus point from me for not being overly loud. The service was great, and the staff was really friendly.

The food was solid Indian fare (yummy paneer), but too spicy for my tastes. Just ate leftovers from here and this was confirmed. My mouth was on fire. Medium was uncomfortably hot. Next time I'll ask for mild.

It's a good choice for a mellow place to grab dinner before a show at the nearby Independent.
author: Mary M.

description: I LOVE!!  LOVE!! this place...this is by far the best Indian Food I've had in a while.  It's a mom and pop kinda place so don't expect too much.  But the service and the food is awesome.  I came here with a party of 9 including a 6 year old who btw loved the naan, and we ordered everything.  Rita, the owner/waitress makes sure that your chai, water, drinks are filled and of course, that you are happy with your food.  She went out of her way to give my daughter a "mango shake" (no charge).  This is definitely a thumbs up and I would go again!!
author: j m.

description:
As others have noted, the service is attentive. The servers are very friendly and the menu is extensive. There are not many choices for desserts, though. Saffron Grill was quick to say that they have wine and beer. I don't usually order either with my Indian food, but that may appeal to some. 

We ordered the chicken tikka masala, which was moist but relatively bland. The vegetable korma had a bite to it and was more flavorful.

Overall, it has standard fare, is probably consistent, and I'd go back, but it didn't wow me.
author: Ellen S.

description:
Ok, so Rita: awesome.  The food: delicious.  

This is a great place to call your own in Alamo Square.  It's off Divis so you might not notice it, but this place has been around a few months.  I love the food and when you say spicy, they don't mess around--which can always be a point of contention for sissy-pants yelpers.  Rita is bubbly, warm, and helpful.  She really makes her customers feel appreciated.

The only disappointing thing about this place is the decor.  Seriously, it's time to bring some color and life to the walls people.
author: Alex P.

description: Saffron Grill is a cozy, intimate restaurant with fabulous North Indian fare. As we stood outside gazing at the menu before entering, a customer picking up an order to go stopped us and said, "If you're trying to decide, this is a great place!" And was he ever right. From the friendly, helpful owner/waitstaff, to the wonderful food, we were so glad we tool the time to find a parking space within walking distance. Mid-dinner, my English husband stopped and said, "This is the best Indian food I've had since I've been in America!" And he's been here over 20 years. Great place! We'll be back as often as possible.
author: Lois S.

description: so used to restuarants being scared of making their food spicy, when I asked for my food extra spicy, saffron grill obliged. It was perhaps the best indian food i've ever had.
author: Jiro A.

description: Tiny, tasty, spicy!  Snag a table in this cozy spot and go nuts.  Last week my table tried the lamb coconut curry and we were wiping the serving bowl clean with our naan.  Since the place is so small you might have to wait for a table to open up, but there are bars right next door and coffee shops across the street where it's easy to spend 20 minutes.  This is a great neighborhood spot for the Divisadero strip.  The only con might be the size (some might feel a little bit cramped).  The walls are covered with colorful artwork though, creating a warm atmosphere.
author: Adam C.

description:
Quite possibly the best Indian food in the city at affordable prices. They do not pretend to look like an high-end Indian place but the flavors in their food really are.
Before I go on with my recommendations of the food,  what I really love about the place is how low key, intimate and family-run it is. The owner/chef has been the chef at 5-star restaurants like Taj in Delhi for many years, so he really knows what he is doing. His daughter and son-in-law run the front of the "house". Both are extremely warm and cheerful. They also showcase beautiful artwork on the walls from local SF artists. 
I am very picky about my Indian food (I am Indian) and IMO 'Saffron' is as good as it gets in the city (another good place that comes to mind is 'Mehfil' but Saffron is better IMHO)
Now to the bite - my absolute favorites here are Butter chicken, Chicken Achar, Aaloo tikki (appetizer) and tandoori. The food is not greasy or oily like in other Indian restaurants.
Only reason I give this a 4 star and not a 5 star is because I reserve 5 stars only for impeccable food, ambience and service (think 'Fleur De Lys')
author: K S.

description: Really good spicy Indian food! Not a lot of space but if you have to wait they take your cell number and reccommed you get a drink at one of the many fine establishments nearby (reppin my hood yo!). Service was awesome; we were the last ones in there, a bit past closing and they never rushed us. I also highly reccommend the pakora! It's actually substantial instea of just mostly fried grease.
author: Rhi G.

description: I fell in love with her, the atchar chicken. We had a mad affair, she was spicy and delicious, me.. human. It was a match made in heaven, don't you see? Now I look forward to our next rendezvous, maybe the naan will join us next time for a ménage à trois. I can't wait.
author: Artur R.

description: Love Saffron Grill. Family owned and run, it's super comfortable atmosphere and friendly service from Rita is always relaxing. The food is super tasty and  fresh (can't emphasize this enough!!) -- YUM! Don't get spicy unless you can really handle it!
author: beth a.

description:
I ate here with some friends and ordered the samosas, chicken tikka masala, palaak paneer and aloo gobi. Everything was incredibly flavorful! The chicken was very moist and delicious, the paneer was the best I've ever had and the aloo gobi had a perfect balance of spices. We also ordered the raita and mango lassi which had the perfect amount of mango flavor. 
The woman who serves at all the tables is so sweet and friendly! She has a great sense of humor and brings a really fun atittude to the experience.
I ate there last night and want to go back today!
author: Meredith S.

description:
Great food.  We had the veggie somosas, chicken korma, lamb vindaloo, and dahl.  Also they modify the spiciness of each dish to your liking.  Be warned...spicy is pretty spicy.  If you like spicy food, I mean seriously like it then their spiciest option is great.  You feel the spice right away but can keep on eating the dish without hurting or it becoming un-enjoyable.  However, if you aren't that great with spice but think you are (ie. like my hubby), then I suggest going for medium spicy setting.  

Great food & great service.  Love that combo.  I will definitely be coming back.
author: Tammy S.

description: This was the best Indian meal of my life. I dad the samosas, naan, fish masala, and doughnut holes in cardamom honey for dessert.You gotta try those. The masala sauce was so good that I saved some to take home and eat again. The main waitress is super sweet and gets you excited about the food. Your average tab will likely be $15-20 a person, but it's very much worth it.
author: James P.

description: This tiny restaurant off Divisadero is about a 90 second walk from my apartment, but I think I'd make the effort to come here even if I had to trek to do it. For a restaurant with 8-10 tables, it feels remarkably un-cramped. The family who run the place are incredibly friendly, and they recognize all the locals, which I love. There are almost always people outside waiting for the next table after 8 or so, probably because the food is so good. Service is friendly and really fast, and if you ask for spicy food, they'll pull no punches. Totally delicious, highly recommended.
author: Mary H.

description: Nicest people ever, they make their own yogurt, cook beautiful north-indian food. Best Indian restaurant in town
author: Alex A.

description:
Finally, a great Indian restaurant in San Francisco!!  I am so thankful that the yelp community led me to this adorable little place.  The service was fantastic.  They were very attentive and friendly.  Also, the ambiance was perfect and romantic.  I love the cute little christmas lights throughout and the soft music...it makes for a very intimate date place.

The food was also wonderful and authentic (it is traditional northern Indian - my favorite).  We ordered appetizers, entrees, and a dessert, but I especially loved the lamb vindaloo and the garlic naan.  I wish it was just a tad cheaper so I could eat here more often.  Nonetheless, I will definitely be back for many more meals to come!
author: Julia J.

description: Been here many more times since the last review and every time has been tasty, satisfying and memorable in all the right ways. I have taken family and friends out here and they all seemed to really enjoy their meals. They are a bit expensive, but considering the amount of food and the quality (and the fact that most Indian food is a bit pricier on average) it is well worth it.
author: Bridget D.

description: I think saffron grill is terrific. We've been there twice and had delivery twice.  So far so good. The food food is delicious and I'm trying to diet. I had a full plate and am not actually hungry but I can hear chicken vindaloo and lamb dish whose name I've forgotten calling me... come in here fatty, you know you want more.
author: ari b.

description: I've been here several times and it's SO delicious! A small quaint venue that has a romantic, home-like feel and the staff are very nice and attentive. The Tikka Masala excellent and has just a bit of a kick! You can round out your meal with a tasty, refreshing Mango Lassi. Although, it's so tasty I start my meal of with it. It's also reasonably priced and good portions (not too big and not to small, just right for this goldie locks!) Can't beat a better lil' nook than this place!
author: Keegan M.

description: Too bad Yelp doesn't offer a 6th-star option-- Saffron Grill deserves it for the incredibly friendly owners and staff.  They always remember us and are even happy to customize orders.  I also love that every time we come they seem to have added a new item to the decor-- this place gives me serious warm fuzzies.  Now if they would just start serving rasmalai...
author: Marie K.

description: Yum!  This is our neighborhood Indian restaurant and by farm my wife and my favorite Indian in the city.  The atmosphere is homey and nice, the wait staff is friendly and helpful, the food is great!
author: Will W.

description: YAY!  A delish Indian joint in my hood!  And they deliver- bonus! Recommend the Butter Chicken: tender & smothered in a fresh, flavorful & chunky tomato sauce and the samosas are some of the best I've ever had.  Warning: I love a good burn, but after reading the reviews, ordered medium spice & was saah-weating. So worth it.  Nice job, Saffron Grill. That's some damn tasty eats!!!
author: Jamie R.

description: Delicious saag paneer and tilkka masala. Very friendly service.
author: Tobias S.

description: I came here because the wait at Nopalito was bananas. This place felt like I was in a friend's house and their mom was cooking for us. Which is fine, by all means, as long as the food is good right? It was pretty tasty and they made it just very spicy too which is always a plus. I hate getting overlooked as whitey mc whiterson, as if I can't handle spicy food. All in all, a pleasant experience, very small interior and not fancy by any means. They also forgot my friend's order of a lamb dish, which seemed weird since we were the only people eating in there. How could the f&% up the only table they were serving? Somehow they managed to. Definitely not a date place, very low key. I would come back to try it again, but not likely anytime soon. I think this is more of a spot if you live in the neighborhood, I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. I
author: Kristy H.

description: Wonderful little neighborhood place to get *GREAT* North Indian food. I've never had a bad dish here - so order all and everything so long as you get a col lassi on the side.
